content:
Viral Integration Detection - HPV & Oncovirus Analysis

Identify viral DNA integration sites in host genomes using chimeric read analysis. Detects HPV and other oncovirus integration events that drive cancer development, with applications in cervical, head/neck, and other virus-associated cancers.

What is Viral Integration?

Viral integration occurs when viral DNA inserts into the host genome, disrupting normal cellular functions. For HPV and other oncoviruses, integration is a critical step in cancer development, often disrupting tumor suppressor genes or activating oncogenes.

Why Detect Viral Integration?

  • Cancer Diagnostics: Integration sites identify high-risk HPV infections progressing to cancer
  • Prognosis: Integration patterns correlate with disease severity and outcomes
  • Treatment Selection: Integration status informs therapeutic strategies
  • Mechanism Discovery: Reveals how viruses drive oncogenesis
  • Biomarker Development: Integration signatures as disease biomarkers

Key Features

  • Chimeric Read Detection: Identifies reads spanning viral-host genome junctions
  • Multi-Virus Support: Detects HPV, EBV, HBV, HHV-8, and other oncoviruses
  • Precise Localization: Pinpoints exact integration breakpoints
  • Comprehensive QC: Quality assessment and trimming with FastQC
  • Interactive Visualization: Genome browser views of integration sites
  • Abundance Quantification: Viral load estimation across samples

Pipeline Workflow

  1. Quality Control: FastQC assessment of raw sequencing reads
  2. Read Trimming: Adapter removal and quality filtering
  3. Host Alignment: Map reads to human reference genome
  4. Viral Read Extraction: Identify reads with viral sequences
  5. Chimeric Read Detection: Find reads spanning viral-host junctions
  6. Integration Site Mapping: Determine precise breakpoint coordinates
  7. Verification: Validate candidate integration events
  8. Visualization: Interactive genome viewers and summary plots

HPV Integration in Cancer

Cancer TypeHPV Integration RateKey Features
Cervical Cancer~85% of casesIntegration disrupts E2, leading to E6/E7 overexpression
Head & Neck Cancer~60% of HPV+ casesOropharyngeal cancers, better prognosis when HPV+
Anal Cancer~90% of casesHPV16 most common, integration in MACROD2
Penile Cancer~50% of casesIntegration associated with aggressive subtypes

Common Integration Hotspots

  • MACROD2: Most frequent integration site in cervical cancer
  • MIPOL1/TTC6: Second most common target, chromosome 14
  • TP63: Tumor protein, integration alters expression
  • FHIT: Fragile histidine triad gene, tumor suppressor
  • RAD51B: DNA repair gene disruption
  • Intergenic Regions: ~40% of integrations occur outside genes

Oncogenic Mechanisms

  • E2 Disruption: Integration breaks E2 gene, removing E6/E7 repression
  • E6/E7 Overexpression: Viral oncoproteins inactivate p53 and pRb
  • Tumor Suppressor Loss: Integration disrupts genes like FHIT, MACROD2
  • Genomic Instability: Integration triggers chromosomal rearrangements
  • Gene Fusion: Viral-host gene fusions with altered function

Supported Oncoviruses

  • HPV (Human Papillomavirus): HPV16, HPV18, and other high-risk types
  • EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): Nasopharyngeal carcinoma, lymphomas
  • HBV (Hepatitis B Virus): Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • HHV-8 (Kaposi's Sarcoma Herpesvirus): Kaposi's sarcoma
  • HTLV-1: Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma
  • MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus): Merkel cell carcinoma

Input Requirements

CSV or TSV samplesheet with the following columns:

  • sample: Unique sample identifier (e.g., patient ID, tumor specimen)
  • fastq_1: Path to Read 1 FASTQ file
  • fastq_2: Path to Read 2 FASTQ file (for paired-end data)

Example samplesheet:

sample,fastq_1,fastq_2
Cervix_Tumor_01,tumor01_R1.fq.gz,tumor01_R2.fq.gz
Cervix_Tumor_02,tumor02_R1.fq.gz,tumor02_R2.fq.gz
Oropharynx_01,oropharynx01_R1.fq.gz,oropharynx01_R2.fq.gz

Sequencing Requirements

  • Data Type: Whole genome sequencing (WGS) or targeted viral capture
  • Coverage: 30-60x for WGS, 500-1000x for targeted enrichment
  • Read Type: Paired-end recommended (2x100bp or 2x150bp)
  • Quality: High-quality Illumina data (Phred >30)
  • Library Size: 300-500bp insert size for optimal chimeric read detection

Main Outputs

  • Integration Site Coordinates: BED/VCF files with breakpoint positions
  • Chimeric Read Evidence: BAM files with supporting reads
  • Viral Abundance: Read counts and copy number per sample
  • Interactive Genome Viewers: IGV-compatible tracks for visualization
  • Integration Summary Tables: Gene annotations, breakpoint details
  • Quality Control Reports: MultiQC with alignment and detection metrics
  • Visualization Plots: Integration frequency, hotspot heatmaps

Integration Pattern Analysis

  • Integration Frequency: How many integration events per sample?
  • Breakpoint Distribution: Where in the viral genome do breakpoints occur?
  • Host Gene Disruption: Which cellular genes are affected?
  • Clonality: Is integration clonal (early event) or subclonal (late)?
  • Viral-Host Orientation: Sense or antisense integration?

Clinical Applications

  • Risk Stratification: Integration predicts progression from infection to cancer
  • Screening: Detect high-risk HPV infections requiring intervention
  • Treatment Planning: Integration status influences therapy choice
  • Monitoring: Track integration patterns during treatment
  • Prognosis: Integration in specific genes correlates with outcomes
  • Liquid Biopsy: Detect circulating tumor DNA with integration signatures

Research Applications

  • Carcinogenesis Studies: Understand viral oncogenesis mechanisms
  • Hotspot Discovery: Identify recurrent integration sites across patients
  • Functional Genomics: Study effects of integration on gene expression
  • Evolutionary Analysis: Track integration events during tumor evolution
  • Biomarker Development: Identify integration signatures for diagnostics

Chimeric Read Detection

The pipeline identifies three types of evidence:

  1. Split Reads: Single reads mapping partially to host and viral genomes
  2. Discordant Read Pairs: Mate pairs where one maps to host, one to virus
  3. Soft-Clipped Reads: Reads with unmapped tails matching viral sequences

Quality Control Metrics

  • Viral Read Abundance: Total viral reads per sample
  • Chimeric Read Count: Number of integration-supporting reads
  • Breakpoint Confidence: Support from multiple read types
  • Mapping Quality: Alignment scores for host and viral regions
  • Coverage Uniformity: Even coverage across viral and host regions

Technical Considerations

  • Integration Detection Sensitivity: Requires sufficient sequencing depth
  • False Positives: Can arise from viral contamination or PCR artifacts
  • Low Clonality Events: Subclonal integrations need higher coverage
  • Complex Rearrangements: Multiple integration sites or inversions
  • Reference Genome: Accurate host and viral reference sequences required

Comparison with Other Methods

MethodAdvantagesLimitations
WGS + viralintegrationGenome-wide, unbiased detectionExpensive, requires high coverage
Targeted CaptureCost-effective, deep coverageRequires known viral sequences
PCR-basedQuick, inexpensiveRequires known integration sites
Southern BlotGold standard validationLow throughput, labor intensive

Validation Strategies

  • PCR Confirmation: Design primers spanning integration junctions
  • Sanger Sequencing: Verify exact breakpoint sequences
  • ddPCR: Quantify integration events with high sensitivity
  • FISH: Visualize viral DNA in tissue sections
  • Orthogonal Sequencing: Validate with different platform (PacBio/Nanopore)

Example Discoveries

  • MACROD2 Hotspot: ~10% of cervical cancers have HPV integration in MACROD2
  • E2 Breakpoints: Most integrations disrupt HPV E2 gene
  • Clonal Integration: Early integration events present in all tumor cells
  • Gene Fusions: Viral-host fusions creating chimeric transcripts
  • Microhomology: Integration uses microhomology-mediated repair

HPV Types and Cancer Risk

  • High-Risk HPV: Types 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59
  • HPV16: Most common in cervical cancer (~55% of cases)
  • HPV18: Second most common (~15%), more adenocarcinomas
  • HPV31/33: Common in head and neck cancers
  • Low-Risk HPV: Types 6, 11 cause warts but rarely cancer

Expected Runtime

  • WGS (30x coverage): 4-8 hours per sample
  • Targeted capture: 1-2 hours per sample
  • Cohort analysis: Scales linearly with sample count
  • Recommended resources: LARGE node for optimal performance
